Nice idea.

A couple updates: CRAN now automatically recognizes and links CC0 files, though providing a copy of the license would still be best practice.

Following my request, OSI considered and did not approve CC0, after over 100 email message thread that also involved several folks from Creative Commons. The reason comes from CC0's clause stating that it addresses only copyright issues; it does not address patent rights. While this was done for simplicity, it raised concerns about inviting patent cases to some in OSI. CC hopes to revise the CC0 license in late 2013 or so to address this (after improving internationalization of the license).

This post is a bit tongue-in-cheek in lamenting viral licenses like the GPL, which serve their place. Viral licenses restrict or discourage reuse, while I hope to encourage reuse for any purpose by providing research software, whose development was already funded by public government grants. For pure code applications, 2-clause BSD works just fine. I frequently use MIT simply because it is almost identical to 2-clause BSD, and is easier to say than 2-clause BSD vs 3-clause BSD vs 4-clause BSD etc.

I continue to CC0 for most of my content because public domain is most permissive, (no need to copy licenses, etc) and more importantly is applicable to data, tutorials, figures, papers and documentation, which I often distribute in combined repositories (/ R package / research compendium). Specifying different licenses for each element (a la Victoria Stodden RRS http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/pa... ) is more cumbersome.

Until such a time as CC0 is OSI approved, it may be useful, if cumbersome, to specify different licences for code (e.g. MIT) and data (CC0), to avoid issues with PLOS etc not allowing CC0 because it isn't OSI approved.

I doubt PLoS would actually have a problem with CC0 code, despite the lack of OSI status. (Google Summer-of-Code has a similar clause). Ironically, some of the folks on the OSI board were kind of surprised that OSI approval might be taken so literally -- there was a time when OSI wasn't quite as picky as it is today.

If you haven't seen it, you might enjoy Victoria Stodden's paper on the reproducible research standard (RRS), basically a way to brand just what you suggest. It doesn't have the widespread recognition or the simplicity of the CC0 approach though.

Thanks for your thoughts and comments here and on twitter; a good discussion!

FYI there is a typo in the href for the Stodden paper you link to tin the original post; there is a trailing right parenthesis. Now I've found it I'll take a read.

Re thoughts: and thanks for yours likewise Carl. Since discussing this (briefly, on Twitter IIRC) with you some time back I've come round a bit to CC0, essentially because of the arguments you raise.

I can't speak for the PLOS Comp Biol folks but I'd be happy to take this issue to them if that helps. I can't see that there would be a problem and the argument for compatibility should get a good hearing. FWIW I also use CC0 on my code where I can for similar reasons.

There was an attempt to get CC0 validated for OSI purposes at one point and it hit upon some very challenging legal issue but I can't recall what it was - just that it felt like a technicality but one that was very hard to get around.

More resources: There is some great, very readable advice about directory layout here: http://nicercode.github.io/blo.... I also particularly like this Software Carpentry slidedeck on data management with respect to version control: http://software-carpentry.org/... (takehome - version manage the readmes, not the data files)

Thanks for the blog post summarizing some of the challenges. I would like to suggest another strategy to make software citable, and that is to publish a "software paper" that describes the software. Several journals have specialized in this, similar to data journals that are sometimes the best place to publish data.

I believe that a DataCite DOI is often the best identifier for scientific software (mainly for the reasons you describe), but unfortunately I am not aware of a software repository that provides that functionality.

In January I attended a workshop on persistent identifiers for scientific software, a blog post summarizing the event can be found at http://home.web.cern.ch/about/....

Hi Martin! Thanks for the comments and link (and for pointing out that CrossRef citation counts aren't so new, and that DataCite doi citation counts aren't so close); your thoughts on these matters are always crisp and insightful.

Having written two "software papers" now (10.1111/j.1095-8649.2012.03464.x, 10.1111/j.2041-210X.2012.00247.x) and reviewed quite a few more, I think these are a very practical approach to software citation, but are without a doubt a hack -- co-opting some existing infrastructure for a purpose it was never designed for, rather than building the correct thing from scratch. I believe we need publications to look more like software repositories, not the other way around. (Among other problems, relying on citations to software papers actively encourages ignoring software versioning). Of course the practice is developed only in light of our current emphasis and infrastructure for publication counts.

Git gives us computationally verifiable versioning through hashes (which I use for notebook entries as well http://carlboettiger.info/2013..., a way to sign author contributions, and more fine-grained provenance thanks to cheap commits and merges. Consequently it seems that using a SHA hash as part of a permanent identifier for code is pretty attractive.

For instance, with a PURL I can construct the identifier: cboettig/ews-review/33dfb58e24ceb5861dad7cf756cffe2c5d66a655 which uniquely resolves at purl.org to a specific commit of that project. The missing piece from this solution is the social contract of a DOI. While I could point the PURL at the new location of the git repository if Github were lost, obviously there's nothing to ensure that this happens. I suppose a publisher/repository could use a similar approach of just forking a repository and appending hashes to the DOI? What do you think? Maybe I'm getting lost down the rabbit hole...

There is one other important aspect of DOIs (at least how CrossRef and DataCite have implemented them): you can search for them by metadata (e.g. author name) in one central location. Automatically generating persistent identifiers locally doesn't give you that.

DOIs are not so good for rapidly changing content, e.g. each commit in a git repo. You could the SHA hash and construct your own identifier (as you suggested, but maybe even easier just as URL), and use the DOI for major software versions - it is probably the stable releases you want to cite and not a specific commit.

If software is published in conjunction with a software paper in a journal whose publisher is a CrossRef member, it is possible to assign a CrossRef DOI to the software as a component, and another to the paper itself. The publisher could use CrossMark to identify significantly different versions. The metadata of the paper could be used to locate the software, but CrossRef doesn't have a discovery metadata set optimized directly software at this time.

Great post. We too squirm when we see somebody use the phrase "DOIs make something citable." As you point out, there is nothing intrinsic about the DOI that makes it a citation identifier. DOIs can (and are) as easily used for supply chain management and inventory control.

But even though it makes us squirm, the truth is the phrase is probably just a clumsy short-hand for saying "the presence of a CrossRef or DataCite DOI serves as an affordance mechanism to indicate that the party publishing the content wishes it to be cited in a scholarly context using a persist-able mechanism." Hardly a great marketing phrase.

We also squirm when we see people say that the presence of a DOI makes is "scholarly" or "official" or "published." Again, none of these things are true.

You say "DOIs are not good for rapidly changing content," but I think this again has more to do more with the way in which CrossRef and DataCite have implemented their systems rather than with DOIs themselves. At the moment, the members of CrossRef and DataCite assign DOIs to items upon publication and at whatever level of granularity they think is appropriate. The underlying assumption behind this workflow is "I think this item might be cited in a scholarly context and therefor I am going to assign a persist-able identifier to it in anticipation of it's being cited".

And when one operates under this workflow assumption, certain things appear impractical (logistically, financially or both). For example, it seems impractical to assign a DOI to every frame of a movie under the off chance that somebody might want to cite that particular frame of range of frames. Similarly it seems impractical to assign a DOI to every version of a rapidly changing dataset.

But what if you changed your workflow assumptions? What if, instead of assigning a CrossRef/DatCite DOI at publication, you only assigned DOIs "on first citation?" This might seem weird at first glance, but it is exactly how URL shortners work. The first time a URL is 'bookmarked' they generate a shortened version of it. After that, they can return the same shortened version to whoever next bookmarks the same URL. There are certainly some logistical and business model issues that would need to be worked out, but CrossRef is looking at some approaches that might make this alternative workflow a possibility. And, as usual, we are more than happy to coordinate with DataCIte on this.

In summary, I think it is premature to discount using DOIs as identifiers for highly-granular and/or rapidly changing content.

Geoffrey - Thanks for your comments -- your thoughts and explanation of how DOIs work as a social incentive of a centralized system, not just a technological redirect, has been very influential to me. Hope I paraphrased you reasonably above. Yes, I agree entirely that DOI is an effective short-hand for precisely that, and it really doesn't matter if most researchers are aware of anything else.

But among researchers wanting to discuss things like how to cite software or blog posts (e.g. see C. Titus Brown's discussion http://ivory.idyll.org/blog/po... ) we probably need to step back and ask what features of a DOI we are trying to capture for these entities. Software is probably on firmer ground with software publications or 'supplemental' DOIs, but I'd love to hear your take on citing blog posts, websites (or "online lab notebook entries" in my own example). Do we need DOI-based identifiers for these things or are other solutions like purls or standard / library repositories with URLs sufficient? What about all these other approaches to web-archiving?

Or to put another way, does the DOI system require only some manageable number of publishers n who receive DOIs from a central source? Can this scale to self-published content such as blogs or is that fundamentally domain of a different tool (and different scholarly discourse?)?

Hi. First- yes, I think you summarized my points very neatly. As for your question re: citing blog posts, and open web data. This is an issue we've been noodling around since 2007 (see this CrossTech posting http://goo.gl/VrHye ) and at least part of my answer lies in my comments to Martin Fenner below.

Let's set aside DOIs for the moment. The same points apply to Purls, NOIDs, Handles, etc.

The first issue is workflow- we (CrossRef/DataCite) currently assume the identifier has to be assigned at publication. If we can flip the workflow and assign the identifier at first citation (a-la-url-shortner) then I think we have the basis for a model for persistently citing any content that can be accessed by HTTP. Just In Time Identifier Generation (JITIG)?

The second issue is the social contract. CrossRef/DataCIte have social contracts with members requiring them to behave in certain ways. Specifically, they are required to update their pointers (URIs). This works because we have a relatively bounded community. It would be nearly impossible to enforce a similar social contract with the "publishers" of blog posts, tweets, etc. So you need a different mechanism here too.

Obviously, we want to ensure that anybody resolving the citation:

a) Sees what the author cited (not an updated version, link spam, etc.)
b) Ideally, Sees it in the same context as the author saw it
c) Ideally, Delivers link-karma to the cited content in context

So imagine a workflow where *anybody* can generate a persist-able identifier for a citation. Anybody else who subsequently generates an identifier for the same URI, get's the already generated identifier (unless the content has changed- see below)

The generation of the identifier triggers several things:

a) It triggers an archive event (LOCKSS, Internet Archive, whatever)
b) It computes a digital signature of the document that can be used to determine if the content has changed (Hard, I know. But I think doable)

c) It stashes whatever metdata it can manage to wheedle out of the resource.

So, as long as the link works *AND* the content does not appear to have changed- then resolving the identifier will link you to the original. If the link breaks or the content appears to have changed, then the identifier resolves to one of the archived copies. Yay for indirection.

The system might never be as robust as a social contract along the lines of CrossRef or DataCite- there are lots of places where it can break- but it would certainly make it easier for researcher to cite open content on the web with a reasonable assurance of persist-ability.

As for the idea of encoding verification hashes in the identifiers themselves- Github notwithstanding, I am generally of the belief that overloading the identifier with semantic information just introduces fragility. Identifiers identify, they don't describe. If you do want a verification hash (or several for different representations), include it in the metadata.

Thanks, this sounds promising! I think the concept of just-in-time-identifiers for rapidly changing content sounds great. Tobais Kuhn is working on something like the digital signatures you mention, so far just for rdf data: https://github.com/tkuhn/hashu...
Obviously gets more tricky with external content (convert to data URIs? ignore css?) or other links.

I suppose an identifier provider with enough clout could convince something like LOCKSS to archive arbitrary URLs that have been cited. Like you say, at least the whole trigger to archived copies provides a reasonable alternative to a social contract. I suppose it would be natural to distinguish between case where the link doesn't work and where the content changes, in case the reader wants to see what the new content has become (a la crossmark).

Yes, of course. If the identifier gets redirected to the archived version, the archived version should certainly provide a link back to the original URI resource so that the researcher can, if they want, go and see if the difference between the two is meaningful. Lots of details like that that I've skipped over. All important.

I'd stick with a minimal statement that's confined to asking permission, though perhaps rather than "Issues Tracker" you should refer to something like "the publicly accessible archive of this paper's revision history", so that people unfamiliar with github get the whole idea without needing to follow the link.

As for the rest, anything that you'd put in the cover letter should probably be in the manuscript itself. You might want to emphasize to the editors or reviewers that you welcome review of the code and checking your manuscripts' claims of reproducibility.

If the paper is in a repository, like github, perhaps you could include the lengthy version as the README.md file. Your short statement could have a link to the lengthy one.

How likely is it that reviewers will understand the concept of issue trackers? I've been wondering about that -- I'm not an academic, I'm a programmer. I've been thinking of making a very small post with tips on creating issues and leaving comments in-context.

Great use of GitHub and dynamic documents for this, and would love to try to publish something using this workflow. If the authors consent to making their work open to discussion by submitting it to a journal that carries out totally open peer-review, put it in a pre-print server and make clear in an open forum such as Haldane's sieve that they encourage everyone (including reviewers) to post comments before publication, surely that negates some of the need to spell everything out in a detailed covering letter? In a situation such as this then consent is obviously given and copyright has been waived, and if reviewers or editors need additional clarification they can just read the blogs? You can see an example of this "real-time open peer review" carried out by the Assemblathon2 team, and the discussions they and their reviewers have had via various blog postings linked from here:

http://assemblathon.org/post/4...

I love the idea and I think it's definitely worth going ahead and including something in your cover letters as part of an attempt to start a broader conversation about this. I suspect that the number of people who will give consent will be quite low (unless the reviewer pool is a particularly nerdy crowd) but I tend to think that it's worth doing this stuff even if it won't actually work right away to start making people comfortable with the ideas. I agree that including a full page explaining the open science is probably a bit too much. That said, I really like Noam's idea of including some of this in the ms. It's novel and having it in the ms will reach an audience that isn't typically reading blog posts on these ideas.

Building on Sheila's suggestion of including a link and Noam's suggestion of changing the language, I'll propose a modified version that's maybe a bit more direct and accessible by folks with less computational background:

"The authors request that the editor and reviewers indicate whether or not it is OK post their (anonymous) comments to a public website to facilitate the revision of the manuscript. More information is available at http://myawesomeexplanation.co...."

Ethan White, Noam Ross, Scott Edmunds, Sheila Miguez,

Thanks for the feedback! Building on the other replies, I like @Ethan White's simple example. I still struggle with how to keep whatever I would write in the README / myawesomeexplanation.com equally clear, consise and compelling to the average reader. I think my list above fails on a bunch of those criteria.

@Scott Edmunds,

I agree with the spirit of your comment, which echos the approach I already take. Submitting to journals that already agree to open peer review would indeed negate the need to ask about this. Unfortunately, I think that would be missing an opportunity to reach a larger research audience who is not already on board with sharing their reviews. Until now I've assumed that those who care about such things can find all the above themselves, and those who don't care, won't. Trevor's example made me wonder if a cover letter could be one place to provide a bridge.

Beyond open reviews, I wish executing the dynamic document, browsing the revision history or finding the relevant lab notebook entries was trivial and self explanatory, but experience suggests otherwise. I haven't had a reviewer try to execute one of my dynamic documents yet. The idea of 'make pdf' can be very compelling to anyone who has worked with Makefiles before ( http://kaythaney.com/2013/06/1... ) but be meaningless to everyone else.

I'm looking forward to what you come up with. I don't know of good conventions out there, but I'm not in this field. Speaking as a non-scientific programmer, I know that I've come across software projects with well organized readmes serving as good entry points in to the project. I'm going to take your example text and see if i can come up with some reasonable looking useful outline for a readme.

Nice post Carl, just a few thoughts. I would suggest in a review these things:

Case: I say avoid camelcase as it's already so hard to remember function names - having to remember case as well is annoying (though Google R style guide recommends camelcase instead of the format function_name).

Testing: testthat makes testing quite easy. Going beyond "tests" in the examples of function docs is not that hard with testthat. And there are convenience functions in devtools to run all examples, all tests, from within R.

Documentation: I would strongly urge any package author to use roxygen2. Makes it easier for a pkg maintainer to do good documentation and others to contribute code and docs.

In the paper: They need motivation for why people should care about the software. Also, a series of use cases for the software in the paper is nice as it gives people a variety of things you can do with it.

Agree though that writing papers about software is not ideal (unless there are significant advances, new ideas, etc.), but for academics it is the only way to get recognition for your work - though hopefully this will change fast. Having said that though, I wonder if papers about software is a good way to reach some academics that may not know about the software otherwise.

Nice post with lots of interesting ideas.

I've done a few software reviews myself and always look at the code, run the examples in the paper etc. I rejected (or was it major revisions?) a paper recently on basis that the code seemed to have been written by three or four people each using a different style. There were camelCase functions, functions with underscores in names, etc. It was a mess for the end user as there was no consistency of style. Scott (schamber7) mentions case too - his point is more one of personal style which should not enter into a review. I really dislike Hadley Wickam's use of _ in function names, mainly because my editor changes _ to <- on first press, but that in no way diminishes the quality of the software.

I don't fully agree on the keep code to a single screen or 20 lines - I have a few functions in a package I've just been updating and to keep the main user-facing function simple I broke the guts out into another non exported function. That hidden function is a couple of screens in length but to make it much smaller would not really achieve much beyond having slightly smaller chunks of code. The chunks are unlikely to get reused elsewhere, I've already abstracted the reusable bits into small functions. So there is a trade off and I will probably spend more time on documenting what currently works than making functions smaller - I may come back to this though as debugging one of these functions is a pain...

Great comments, thanks. I should have explained the 20 lines idea better. I actually don't care about this for style, but this issue arose in some offline discussions about software reuse. Consider this article about Knuth and literate programming: http://www.leancrew.com/all-th...

The crux of the piece is that a solution superior to Knuth's is available thanks to the unix philosophy of small tools that do one thing well. While I think that has nothing to do with literate programming, I think it has a lot to do with scientific programming. We trust those small unix tools, while we don't trust scientific software (or we lambast those who do trust it: http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/scie... ). I can't help but think that if only we wrote smaller functions, we could start to accumulate a base of reliable, reusable functions and start to build some reliable, shared infrastructure. As it stands, you are best off actively avoiding reuse of other software researcher-made as it just gets you into trouble -- See O'Meara's comments on this here: http://carlboettiger.info/2013...

Wow, I find this extremely thought provoking.. I've reviewed comparative methods software papers, particularly for MEE, but, well, not to that detail. I almost never have read the actual code, I don't have the time it would take for me to read it and understand it, especially not with MEE's two week review intervals. Usually it takes me hours to read anyone else's code. I normally have to rewrite it line-by-line to understand it. I think the only thing that would makes me read the code is if I found a bug and I wanted to be helpful by pointing out where the bug is.

Yes, R packages should have detailed documentation, including examples. However, the things that will break aren't the examples because R CHECK or the author has already run them. So I try to do new things and/or run it on a different dataset. Play with the function like I was a real user, cause real users are great for breaking functions. Examples generally tell me nothing about how robust the software is.

If the paper isn't specifically a software paper, say its a methods paper with some attached software that does the method, I try using the software if its included in the review materials. I usually find enough to complain about with the method and the paper itself that when the software isn't available, I don't bother.

If it all runs, I also generally try to see if there's anything that would confuse me as a user. I'm a paleontologist by training but I keep getting asked to review things for MEE, so I try to look at it as I'm being asked to bring my own background in. I ask 'what will confuse the shit out of another paleontologist who might stumble on this?'. You know, the sort of thing a confused paleontology person might ask on R-Sig-Phylo, probably because no one bothered to attach a "Cannot Use With Fossils" sticker to it. Maybe that sounds petty, but there's a growing community of paleo people interested in comparative methods and no one is bothering to think what sort of traps those poor fools will fall into. We shouldn't blanket assume everyone is coming to the door with an ultrametric tree in comparative methods.

There's other things I get concerned about too, like whether the software is making a user think enough about sources of uncertainty in the results they get, but maybe that's more to do with reviewing the method than the software.

When you say cite your dependencies, you don't mean put the dependency citations in CITATION right? I think its just obvious that a software paper should cite the packages it uses. Absolutely, people should do that. Frankly, this should be done in non-software papers too. I got a little disturbed, if not angry, when I sar a reviewer suggest that citations to ape and R are superfluous if an author is already citing geiger. Ooof!

So, looking at your list, I'm pretty certain you would have rejected my paleotree paper. I don't pass optional arguments in any of the functions that call optim (it never even occurred to me to do that!) and some of my functions are freaking monsters, like cal3TimePaleoPhy, which is around 500 lines. But, hey, the things paleotree does are things people need to do, particularly me for my dissertation, and so I wrote it. I DO have a github, I do write detailed documentation and I do use imports rather than depends.

I think Pennell pointed me in the direction of the Google R style guide originally, so I came love to camelCase, although my argument terms can be a little inconsistent. I also merge styles a little bit... bin_timePaleoPhy, for example. I have my own, complex reasons for that. If I saw someone with inconsistent styles in their own package, I might suggest they might now want to do that, but I wouldn't be too concerned about it.

I never received any formal training in computer science or code (I was taught Matlab by a geochemist who had started out with punch cards, and I learned R from Mike Foote, Dick Hudson and a lot of trial and error). So, this object oriented code philosophy? I don't really understand it. Its been explained to me a bunch of times by well-meaning people, I read your post (Carl), I kind of see how diversitree makes use of it, and Pennell suggested a way I might adjust one function in paleotree ito make it more OO. But I don't really grok it, nor a lot of other issues I see discussed sometimes in scientific computing. I don't think I could critique anyone on that point.

To return to your initial statement, I think a review of the software paper is a review of the software, but also the paper as a guide to using that software. A software paper should be useful to readers to understanding the software package, but not a replacement for detailed help files either. But, reading the above makes me feel like I've been doing a disservice by reviewing software papers for MEE. Maybe I should just pass on them in the future?

David,

Wow, great comments. Thanks for tackling the main issue head on -- that is just the push back I wanted to hear. No doubt we all put different amounts of emphasis on reviewing the paper vs reviewing the software, and it's certainly not up to me to decide. (Hopefully we'll get some editors to comment on how they see the issue). As I say in the opening, we're kind of hacking the publication system already to get a citable object, so one avenue is to hack it as a peer review system for software too. Hacks aren't meant to be good long-term solutions, and perhaps the community should push back against this idea and say software quality / review needs to find its own mechanism and not expect journal editors and reviewers to handle these issues at all.

On R CMD check examples, that only works if the examples are there in the first place (which is all I'm asking for -- I recently reviewed a paper in which all examples were commented out.) A testthat suite would be great but I'm not trying to pick favorites or be too specific about stylistic choices. I like your description of how you run examples and usually try to do something like that too. But we also need automated tests to capture unexpected changes.

On citations, you got it. use CITATION file for your own paper, and be sure to cite the software and papers used as dependencies (e.g. citations to OUCH should cite Butler and King 2004 Am Nat, as it says in the CITATION file, and not just the software).

On style, camelCase, etc, I avoid this topic because I don't really want to start a flame war; like many other elements of software practice each has its camps. The same can be said about object oriented programming. I don't care about either of these except with respect to interacting with other software. I recommend using S3 classes not because I think all software should be object oriented, but because this lets the software plug into a huge existing set of methods in R based on generics such as coef, update, and simulate.

On paleotree, you say the magic words -- it does what a lot of people need. Overall I am hugely in favor of people sharing whatever code they have (I am a big fan of Nick Barnes: "publish your code, it's good enough"). However, I also think we could all benefit from a shared infrastructure we can trust. To have that, at minimum I think we need code that is modular (e.g. the short functions), documented, and tested. Without those things, it's hard to trust code, and hence we can't build on work that is already done.

Thanks again for sharing and I hope you do continue to review software papers however you see fit. I hope by discussing what we review as a community we can all both write better reviews and have a better idea of what it means to have peer-reviewed software. In the end, I think it is reuse of users and developers, not peer reviewers, that will determine what software is truly valuable.

Do any of the journals have standards or expectations for this sort of thing? I would expect that the Journal of Statistical Software, for instance, has some minimum requirements for software quality, but I don't see anything in its instruction for authors (http://www.jstatsoft.org/instr.... It's all about accessibility reproducibility, and licenses. Nor do I see anything over at MEE on software quality (http://www.methodsinecologyand.... Things like tests, citations, license could easily be articulated by the journal's instructions to authors (and reviewers) and act as a basic quality filter, while things like clean objects and small functions can be debated by the reviewers.

Really nice post. You might be interested in the `LoadandCite` command I put in the repmis R package: http://christophergandrud.gith... . It basically allows you to load packages and automatically generate a BibTeX file with them. If, for example all of the packages used for a knitr paper are loaded with `LoadandCite` then every time the document is knitted it will update the citations (great for keeping the package versions cited synced with those used to make the document).

That's a fantastic idea. For all that useless text spent on how to dot our i's and cross our t's in manuscript format instructions, journals could do a lot by requiring some of the most basic necessities of software design.

When reviewing R packages, formally or informally, I look at how well the package conforms to the R norms; does it walk, talk and quack like R? I don't see the point of writing packages in R if the author is going to ignore how the base of R works, how the language works etc.

OO is one component of that. I'll use some examples from paleotree here to illustrate the point, not to be (hopefully) an arse but for relevance. For example taxicDivCont(), taxicDivDisc(), and phyloDiv() all have a plot argument. A more R-standard way of doing this would be to have those functions return an object with a class (via class(foo) <- "bar", towards the end of the function definition before you return the object foo. Then you write a function plot.bar() which includes the code to draw a plot. That way you separate the data analysis code/step from the plotting step, it is natural to R users to generate an object and then plot it, etc. How many times have you done lm(foo ~ bar, data = foobar, plot = TRUE)? As well as separating the two code blocks, the user doesn't end up rerunning the data-analysis/generation code just to redraw the plot - they can just plot it again using plot().

Another example for a potential change is taxa2cladogram(). The docs indicate that the first argument is an object returned by simFossilTaxa(). So a more R-ish way of writing this would have been to have a generic function as.cladogram() with a method (function) as.cladogram.simFossilTaxa(). The user would just use as.cladogram(foo) with foo an object of class "simFossilTaxa". In the future you might want to convert other types of object to a cladogram so you just add a new as.cladogram() method for the new class (type) of object.

Doing this actually gets very simple if you stick to S3 classes (as I use above) and you end up with code that is more R-like. Why is this good, well if you do your own thing in your package a user has to unlearn the R way of thinking and learn how to use the package. The user can't rely on skills they've acquired through previous R usage and apply it to the package. Given R's steep learning curve, doing things to make using one's package easier is to be appreciated.

Please don't take this as a criticism of paleotree; I don't know the package nor how it works or what it intends to do. I merely used it as an example to highlight where taking a more R-like approach and R's simplest form of OO may help the user experience.

Not that I know of. While they provide style guidelines to authors, most journals do not really tell a reviewer what criteria to use in any event. While the above might be reasonable to have as my personal guidelines, I don't think we expect the journal to tell us how to review either papers or software. There certainly is value in that process being an emergent property of the community rather than some dry journal guidelines. (Okay, a scoring rubric might be helpful).

I hope that in simply being transparent about how we review, we might have a bit more consistent standard (again, a perspective not unique to software papers).

I'd love to hear others weigh in on this. Should journals provide clearer guidelines on authoring and reviewing software papers? Or should this be left up to some other mechanism?

Carl-

I think it partly depends on the statement you make in your post: are we reviewing the software itself when we review a software paper? If so, then it seems reasonable for journals *could* require certain guidelines for the software.

Whether they *should*... well, if you would be willing to reject any software paper for not having certain attributes (such as those you describe in your post), then I think it would ideal to have those spelled out in the journal guidelines, rather than discover them post-review and waste the author's time, the editor's time and the reviewer's time.

Indeed - might help improve the quality of software along with it. If authors can see that they need to have documentation, open licence, unit checks etc as good practice to get into print that is an incentive to do these things.

As Carl points out, publishing software is a bit of a hack of the scientific paper model and whilst for true scientific papers we all know the community norms through practice/grad school etc, what we expect from a software paper may need to be spelled out for a while.

Carl,

I'll respond to your comments point by point.

I have no perspective on how we should handle academic software publication. I do wonder to what degree generational gaps will create a difficulty with implementing any new system of review for academic software itself. I once was told by an older professor (a full professor in his prime, not an emeritus) that it was nice I liked submitting to those new online journals, but how many older guys like himself actually can find time to keep track of them? Sometimes, I think we forget that plenty of established faculty don't know what Twitter is. At least in my field full of old fossils (hah, a pun), I'm pretty certain we're pretty far away from any new system being adopted. I do think journal review of software is better than nothing at all, which generally means no trackable citation at all, which has been the norm in paleontology (sometimes not even a mention!). So, the journal review system is the one we've got, the one we'll probably have for a while to come and so we have to deal with the practical difficulties such a kludge presents.

Yes! I agree completely about having examples. I was just saying it does nothing to ensure the code is robust (i.e. playing with the arguments doesn't cause unexpected failures), which I think is something we should evaluate in reviewing software. I apologize if it seemed like I was disagreeing on that point. Documentation and examples for R CHECK are absolutely necessary.

I've considered at length why I wrote the response to your post as I did (although I was also responding to Scott and Gavin's comments), and I think what I wanted to say was this: What are the gatekeeping rules we want to set that would actually decide whether we allow for people to academically publish software or not? I just feel some of the things you stated as requiring major revisions or reject/resubmit aren't things I'd want to blanket force all academic software authors to do. I'll get to Gavin's comment about OO in a bit, but here's the thing: most academic programmers have zilch experience in computer science, but they're the same ones (sometimes, maybe, the only ones) willing to produce the software that does a large number of tasks. If we required object oriented programming, I don't think we'd benefit from the diversity of academic software that we have. Citations are an important incentive to get people to release their code to begin, if we say 'only if you break your giant functions down, only if you do this' then we endanger that diversity. I'd rather have a lot of software that isn't as well written or laid out as we'd like.

One thing that I think we should ask of software, or reall all methods development, has to be proof that it actually works. And that often means simulation tests, across several different scenarios. This isn't something I've enforced in most of my past software reviews, but it is something I'm becoming convinced is something we need more of.

Gavin-

With respect to making use of R's particular attributes, I'll openly state that I don't think that's important. I think the reason we use R is because its relatively easy for many people to learn to use, has an ever increasing scientific audience and an enormous base of useful packages to build off of. I use R because ape exists. I haven't seen anything that offers all the tools I need for paleotree except in ape, and I don't feel like reinventing that wheel. And I think that's why most people use R. While I agree it is optimal that packages should take advantage of the qualities of their programming language, my contention in this conversation is that isn't a criteria we should judge that decides acceptance of the software in the academic literature.

Yeah, I love running a function and having it make a plot at the same time. Lots of paleotree functions have plot arguments. It's not meant to be a terribly useful plot (like, publication quality or even useful in research) but its useful to me for diagnostic purposes and, also, pedagogically when I use paleotree as a teaching tool. But that's besides the point. Thanks to your examples, I understand better how OO should apply in the case of paleotree. I wouldn't alter it now just to meet that criterion (that would just confuse the people who do use it) but I had to make significant modifications for other reasons I would strongly consider (as the Harmon lab chose to, for geiger 2.0).

Now, I can see how OO is useful (although, honestly, I don't think R's learning curve is that high, but we could debate that all day), but I do question whether that's an attribute we'd want as a gatekeeper for software papers. Carl lists it up there as something to ask for as a major revision. To me, that means its something we are going to demand is in the paper as a reviewer for it to be accepted. If an author wasn't willing to do that or wasn't willing to put the effort into understanding how to redesign their software to be object oriented, would we say no go? I think that's the crux of this matter. Maybe we don't all agree on what the job of a reviewer and an editor is, but to me its the job of a gatekeeper, to state what is needed for a work to pass through that gate into peer-reviewed heaven. We can make helpful suggestion that would improve a paper, but as reviewers we have to keep separate what we see as needing to be changed so to recommend acceptance and what is just our preference.

And hahah, I enjoy criticism. Even I make fun of paleotree. I'm only a code monkey relative to other paleontologists. But the package has its uses, ya' know? I admit that maybe if had gone the OO route or made other changes we've discussed in this thread, I would attract more users and gain the fruit of a greater number of citations for paleotree. But is it a necessary element to call someone's package good, acceptable software? That's the question I ponder.

I hope my arguments on this point are getting clearer.

How many lines is a typical R package that you review? I have worked on packages in C, Fortran, and Python that are several thousand to hundreds of thousands of lines long. It's hard to imagine reviewers actually reviewing the software much in that regime. For the one software paper I've written, the reviewers only reviewed the paper itself, as far as I could tell.

@Scott. phytools has a number of functions with camelCase function names. My reason for adopting this was to avoid conflict with generics. For instance plotSimmap instead of plot.simmap. (Since the object is of class "phylo" not "simmap" and there is already a plot.phylo in the ape package.) I kind of like it....

Hi Carl. I have to agree largely with David here. All of this is excellent "best practices" programming advice, which I think you are very generous to take the time to provide as a reviewer.... however, as threshold gatekeeping criteria for publication, they strike me as a trifle arrogant.

Here are a couple of more serious issues that you do not mention:
1) Scalability. Sometimes software written by scientists (including myself in earlier versions of phytools) is so poorly (and unnecessarily poorly) written that it does not scale easily, if at all, to the size of problem or dataset typical of empirical application.
2) The authors are publishing a method, not a software package. If the software publication entirely duplicates an existing method paper (i.e., they are "double-dipping"); or if the authors are circumventing what would be more appropriately a review of a method, not a program, then (in my opinion) the paper should probably not be published.

I have to disagree with 2 - at least in part. Many software papers I see/review are not describing a new method but a new software that implements that method. I see nothing wrong in this - a method paper will have the theoretical information and algorithm details, the tests and comparisons. A software paper such as published by the Journal of Statistical Software doesn't need all these things, but instead offers an introduction to the software, how to analyse certain test cases or examples and illustrates the scope of the software, motivation behind it etc. Double-dipping is not OK, but for a software paper to be useful it will most likely contain a review/summary of the theory behind the method.

You mention "best practices" and that it might be somewhat "arrogant" to hold software authors to such ideals as part of the publication process. However, I would argue that this is exactly what we do each and every time we review a science paper. Didn't follow experimental design "best practices" ? Reject! Didn't follow statistical "best practices"? Reject! I don't see why we cannot hold software authors to higher standards when we expect no less of the science reporting/reviewing we do!
Most R packages tend to be shorter than what you describe and are more conveniently broken down into discrete chunks than perhaps with the average C/C++/Fortran program.

Thanks Liam!

I was really hoping you would comment, I think your perspective is invaluable here.

First, just to clarify: As I say above, my calling some of these things "reject and resubmit" is tongue-in-cheek. The functional difference I see in anything but "accept" is the time given the author to reply anyway, so these are really just things I'd like to see. I believe the acceptance/rejection is the editor's decision, so as a reviewer I focus on technical feedback.

I am also trying to keep my list more narrow than generic "best practices". I think where I largely differ with Dave is that "the software works" is the primary criteria. My criteria is built around a very similar goal: the "software might work several years from now." Without test cases or active development, I don't think any software will make that mark.

Meanwhile scaling is important, but in my opinion something that happens when it is needed (no premature optimization etc), so I intentionally left this off my list.

Double-dipping is a great point, but I am often unclear on where to draw the line. Is just running the method on some data that hasn't been analyzed before sufficient? Perhaps this again exposes the 'hack' of software publishing. I never believed it was a great solution, but what is the alternative to provide citable and reviewed software?

I appreciate the feedback, but perhaps failed to convey that this post stems from my uncertainty as to whether I should be reviewing the software at all, and if so, how? not from any belief in the superiority of my own approach.

Thanks for your response David. I was remiss in not stating in my reply that I wouldn't reject a software paper because they didn't follow the language norms. I would remark on them in the review but not use that as a rejection criterion.

Changing palaeotree now might be less work than you think - leave the plot argument in the function, but just stick a class on the returned object and write a plot() method for that class. Both the method and the main function could use the same plotting code if you arranged things properly. Whether this works or not is whether what is returned by the function is sufficient to redraw the plot with. But I agree - there is no point changing things now just for the sake of meeting language norms.

We will have to agree to disagree about the learning curve of R - I find most of R pretty easy, but I've taught enough people now on R courses to know that the majority don't - and I must have taught in the region of 400 people at this point, mostly PhD students/candidates, post docs or above.

What might be helpful in software reviews papers is that alongside the paper, the reviewer can supply a review (in the vein of a book review) that critiques the sorts of things Carl and I have describe. The authors can respond should they wish. So the software could be published as long as it was shown to work in some cases (examples) but these more subjective criteria could be addressed in by the critic-style review.

I was just about to write what Gavin did. I can think of several examples of pure software papers being published in MEE. For instance, the popdemo package pretty much implements methods for examining demographic transients that had previously been described elsewhere. Such papers are useful, in providing an introduction to the community, and also incentivizing authors to develop software.

It's probably useful that have methods and software reviewed separately, with the software paper getting more of the treatment that Carl described above (by reviewers that the editor picks for software expertise). This also helps avoid the second situation you describe, where the authors are avoiding scrutiny of the method or software by highlighting the other.

I don't claim to read every line of code, (though for the cases I've come across, that's actually very do-able). Citing dependencies, license, development repository, etc can all be checked by reading the paper alone. Hopefully from the paper it is clear whether the software has some test functions too, right?

So it is more of a question whether anyone in your area would reject a paper based on failing some of these basic elements?

I'm quite skeptical of peer review as a good system to validate code anyway -- long development history and a big user base seem like better criteria to me -- but I feel an implicit assumption that code associated with 'software papers' has been vetted to some level. I'd love to be wrong, my life would be easier then.

I think we eco/evo types could learn a lot from how these issues are handled in other fields where publishing 'software papers' may have been around a lot longer, and where most reviewers are more familiar with coding practices.

In Liam's defense, one can see why it appears more arrogant to state "my all-mighty criteria" on a public webpage without reference to any one paper than simply writing it in private review. I'm also sure editors like Liam would be happy to have more opportunities to tell reviewers not to be arrogant, but they don't really get that opportunity in traditional peer review.

That said I really appreciate both your points here!

Unfortunately, scientific methods can change quickly, and the software can have a rather small niche, so we can't count on time or the user base to validate the code. Some quality filtering is necessary.

However, this might be an argument for another review criterion: reuse. We can tell authors when their code replicates functions that are implemented already in established software packages, and request that they replace their ad-hoc solutions with ones that have been validated.

Thanks to all for great replies; I appreciate the feedback!

I have just added an edit to clarify that I do not see any of these things as "gatekeeping;" I haven't said anything about criteria to simply "reject" a paper. As a reviewer I believe I just provide my professional opinion and expertise to the editor who is the real gatekeeper -- peer review isn't a vote, right?

It is quite likely that hacking the publication system for software review is simply a bad idea. However, it sounds like most commenters believe a reviewer should pay some attention to the software, we just have mixed ideas on what. My own criteria stem from the belief that we need to promote stability and extensibility over fragile novelty.
@liamrevell:disqus Ah, I see what you mean, that seems reasonable.

I just think it's great that you both put forth deliberate reasons for your choices of syntax.
(Technical nitpick - you both agree that dots be reserved for S3 functions, @Scott just suggests underscores while @Liam suggests camelCase).

I think this reflects the bigger philosophy that as authors of software we should be cognizant of how our contribution fits in the context of existing software ecosystem (e.g. Namespaces, extensibility, code reuse), just as we expect publications to be cognizant of existing literature.

Cool, thanks for the link! Speaking of citations in knitr, you might be interested in my knitcitations package, which provides inline and bibliographic formatting of citations in knitr using bibtex files or DOIs or URLs to the cited work. See http://carlboettiger.info/2012...

p.s. your link above has an extra ')' at the end (stupid disqus) that you might want to remove.
@cboettig:disqus yes, reserve dots for S3 methods. - and therefore seem not ideal in standard function names.

I have much lower standards than you. For review of software, I focus much more on usability issues. Can a typical user know how to get her/his data into the package's functions, is there adequate documentation, if they type ?newphypackage will they get something useful, etc. I'll typically poke around in the source code a bit, but I don't really address the software engineering issues you raise. There's already a Prof. Brian who will check carefully for R compliance for CRAN submission.

Maintainability is an interesting issue. When one publishes an empirical paper, it's based on work that was done over a fixed period of time. Other than making material available (which often isn't done, but that's another issue), once it's published the responsibility of the author is done: she/he is not expected to rerun an experiment if someone later proposes an alternate hypothesis, or even if they find what could be a flaw ("that model of sequencer tends to falsely record some C's as G's"). The author instead moves on to other publishable work. For software, some people commit to responding to every user bug or request (Liam is a great example of this), constantly improving software. Your criterion for a bug tracker suggests an expectation for this. However, many people publish software as "this is the tool I built and used", with no expectation for uncompensated improvements later, just as empiricists finish a study, publish it, and move on. A grad student might produce very useful software but then decide to go into a different field: I'd still publish the paper, knowing that the software would not be improved further by that individual. This also gets into broader issues about credit for work and funding: how to sustainably get people to spend time improving existing software, when #publications matters more than #citations and when it's much easier to get funding for new work ("transformative") than improving old work?

Unit testing comes under the maintainability discussion. If it's clear from the paper that the software works right now, unit tests just are a way of testing if it will work in the future as things change. It's a good practice to adopt as a developer, but as a reviewer I focus on the artifact I have in hand, not so much future-proofing it. I might suggest it, but certainly would not require it for acceptance, if I'm convinced on other grounds that the software works.

I think software would be greatly improved by adopting your suggestions, but if it works well already, serves a use case, and just doesn't meet modern software engineering specs, I'd be very reluctant to impose reject and resubmit on it. I think the way to get these adopted is more on the encourage/teach side than the reject side. Open source software is still new enough in our field that there's a risk of making people go closed source to avoid the hassle of review (web services seems to be a new way to sneak something in as closed source: it's not obvious to most people that a website with an open API but no availability of the code is as closed as a program distributed only as binaries).

I think there's plenty of room for one-off software/scripts in publications, but if the paper is a *software paper*, in which the primary work being reviewed is the software rather than the results of an experiment, I would think the software merits higher scrutiny and standards.

I can definitely see this viewpoint. I think I'm coming from the perspective that the most interesting/important papers are those reporting new discoveries or new methods, and I see software papers mostly as placeholders: for software itself to count for hiring/tenure you (currently) need something to stick a DOI on for citation and a discrete publication to list on a CV. I expect this sort of need to decline as altimetrics develop (and become resistant to spoofing). I haven't handled a lot of papers where the software itself, rather than the method it implements, is the focus, but for that sort of paper higher standards are important, though I'm still not sure about long term maintainability as something to use in evaluation.
Since I use Sweave to run my scripts, do you know if there is an easy way to get the references formatted within the pdf during one Compile?

With Sweave this should be straight forward; just generate a bibtex file of the packages, e.g.

write.bib(c('bibtex', 'utils', 'tools'), file='references')

and then cite as you would in LaTeX with the citation handles (e.g. `\cite{utils}`, etc), and include references.bib in the latex bib list.

You can also do this with my knitcitations package, but that is aimed more at knitr/markdown users who don't have access to latex's bibtex, or who want to look up citation data on the fly by the DOI or URL....
Note that derivations for this appear in Tuesday's entry: http://carlboettiger.info/2013...

Your protocol for review makes complete sense to me if the software component is not the central output of the paper. I'll strongly disagree with you on unit tests. If anyone submits a software paper without unit tests, that's a huge red flag and raises plenty of doubts about usability. To me it might be a whole lot more trouble that it's worth. More recently (thanks to Geoff Oxberry) I've been advocating writing tests first, then writing the code.

Ah, well, see, we have different ideas about what those statements reviewers say mean (which I was beginning to suspect we did). If someone tells me to change something and puts a label 'major revisions required' on it, as you did, then I take that as 'I'd better change that or have a good reason why I can't, or else this reviewer will not recommend my paper to go any further'. At least in my experience, unless a reviewer is blatantly antagonistic, editors mostly just parrot the reviewer's recommendations.

(All of this is kind of scary. If you and I could have different expectations about the significance of statements in a review, what does that mean for peer review in general?)
I think if there's one syntax aspect we can all agree on, it's to reserve dots for S3 methods.

Brian, I love both your comments. Like Liam Revell, you seem to point to the fact that publishing something that is purely a 'software paper' is indeed a somewhat fragile hack merely to get a citation and DOI, and hijacking it further (e.g. as a tool to promote sustainable software infrastructure) is futile. Is that a fair paraphrase or am I overstating your position?

While I love the spirit of teaching best practices instead of rejecting poor practices, I think that we must first change incentives to change behavior. I believe that to suggest that teaching better coding (or better math, or scientific communication, or whatever your pet issue is) is _the_ solution to a society that does not reward these things is futile at best.

Many folks interested in promoting the recognition of diverse research outputs point to software publication as an important tool. Will it ever also be a tool to promote sustainable infrastructure (a la unit tests, continuous development repositories, etc) or do we need an entirely different route to that goal (or perhaps those issues take care of themselves given time?)
Then, crap. phytools violates this also. Oh well!

Ok, concrete example. The treebase package (https://github.com/ropensci/tr... has a test dir and uses testthat, but I don't see any tests implemented. Assuming I haven't missed something (a dubious assumption, and correct me if I'm wrong), it doesn't do any real unit testing. Most tests would be dependent on TreeBase being functional. What sort of tests would you add to treebase to make sure it's working well?
By the way, Carl, in my experience you are a terrific (& very constructive) reviewer.

You're absolutely correct, Gavin, scientific peer reviewers also often display the same kind of "my way or the highway" arrogance - I know I've been guilty of this - but that's a topic for another day!

It's one thing to encourage good practices - it's another thing to say "you didn't do this exactly as I would have - see you later!"

@Gavin. You're right that #2 is a more nuanced criterion than I laid it out to be. Publishing a software note on top of a method paper is not always "double-dipping," it just sometimes is (in my humble opinion, of course).

Concrete example = great idea. First off, I expect the treebase package to fail a lot of my criteria, and I also expect the current implementation to become obsolete once we can just pull all treebase in NeXML from Github into R, since the nexml is much richer. The contribution there in that paper, in my mind, is much more in the ideas and proof of principle.

But actually treebase has several tests built in. Using `devtools`, I can run: `document(".")` and then `run_examples(".", run=FALSE)`, to run all the examples in the test (most of which use \dontrun to avoid overtaxing CRAN's servers and to pass check when an internet connection is not available..). Not totally automatic but not bad.

Then there's the dynamic version if the manuscript: https://github.com/ropensci/tr... which can be knit to rerun the examples shown. If the api breaks, these should break, making it clear to a user that the package isn't functioning as it was once written.

I'm honestly surprised to see that I have testthat functions in there as well. I don't use testthat nearly as much as I should, I didn't think I even knew about it back then. Note that the tests themselves are implemented in /inst/tests, and there are only two of them.

I wouldn't hold up treebase or rfishbase as perfect examples. We're all learning, and writing those papers was part of my learning. But simple practices like examples and using a dynamic document for the manuscript do provide one way for some automated testing. Like I say above, as a reviewer I'm not insisting on formal unit tests using a dedicated suite, I'm not looking for 100% code coverage in tests, etc etc. Just some way to quickly run the basic functions and see if they execute.

I wouldn't go so far as to say that "hijacking it further ... is futile". I think adding these criteria to peer review would be effective in forcing a change, in the same way that people submit to genbank/dryad/treebase if (and only if, sadly) the journal requires it (and often not even then). However, I do have hope for teaching as a strategy. Open sourcing software still isn't required by many journals, but people now usually do so due to cultural expectations ("why are you hiding your source code"), fostered by various classes and other training as people learn. Soft pressure ("as a reviewer, I'd suggest....") can work, but hard limits ("I require ....") might be premature.
Drat. and I was hoping that after posting this no one would ask me to review software ;-) ... at least some evidence the plan is working: https://twitter.com/omearabria...

And that's not what I meant. We review papers to check mistakes haven't been made, to determine if methods are appropriate, that results support conclusions etc. In many cases (though not all, eg PLOS One) we're asked to comment on quality, novelty, etc which often is the deal breaker to getting into a journal*. Why can't we do the same for software? it works, it does what it claims, but it is poorly documented, slow, abuses the software paradigm of language X, buggy, so I suggest reject? I don't see this as arrogance. And it is not about doing something my way or I'll try to silence you - its about giving a full and frank critique of the paper and the software.

Then it is up to the editor to decide whether they want to offer the authors space in the journal to espouse their software's virtues.

* I actually think the quality/impact/novelty of publishing is the wrong criteria to assess. But if that's what journals want they should get it for software papers as well as the usual fare. In those journals that don't require this type of review I can usually comment on the paper right there next to it on the journal's website.publisher's
Indeed - a software paper should be for something more than just the script and a few functions someone cooked up to do a particular something for a certain study.

If R can't be consistent here... ;-) You'd need to break that rule for any function trying to ape the as.foo() naming style or the read.foo() or write.foo().

That is a little cheap; R Core now stipulate that no new functions in R itself will have a . in their name due to confusion with S3 methods, but still :-)

Wow - what a comment thread. You've really hit a nerve here, Carl. For what it's worth, I completely side with you. And as @liamrevell:disqus says, you're a very constructive reviewer (and given you sign your reviews, it especially makes sense to put your criteria here).

For people arguing that tests are not required if you're not going to maintain a package, I'd actually argue the opposite. If you mostly want to drop a package off and walk away, tests are the easiest way of demonstrating correctness. They also help anyone who picks the package up to extend it later (surely a good thing) by avoiding regression. And as schamber7 says - with testthat they're easy to do.

One thing that doesn't seem mentioned is performance. If your paper makes a mention of being "fast", be prepared to justify the algorithms used, and provide some benchmarks. When I've reviewed code before, spotting bottlenecks is often fairly easy to do (a little profiling and poking) and it's been clear that the authors have not done that. Perhaps we need to try to foster a more informal code review amongst like-minded people before hitting the more adversarial peer-review system.

However, getting the time to review all the code and the paper is hard. Especially in the light of all the pieces (usually written by journal editors) berating reviewers for taking their time, and journals requiring faster and faster turnarounds. This doesn't just apply to software papers either, but models too. For papers of this type, the *entire* research project is there, able to be inspected, rather than with more empirical work where you tend to see only results and hints about collection. But then, I'm a slow reviewer, so perhaps I'm just complaining.

Anyway, thanks Carl. I'll probably link to your criteria next time I do a software paper review, at least until the journals formalise this themselves.

@richfitz:disqus thanks for your thoughts Rich, I was hoping I might hear from you on this. All good points. I'm not sure I side with *myself* on this one, as far as whether these are reasonable things to critique or expect to be critiqued in a review. As you suggest, an informal code review might be the way to go -- probably doesn't matter if it is before or after the software gets it's 'citable' publication. This makes me wonder how far one could go with a community blog, a la nicercode or Haldane's Sieve style, reviewing software packages in this manner (maybe with some five star scoring system or something).

It makes sense to outline the best case, and then see how things slide from there.

At the same time, probably it's important not to set the bar *too* high, so that people feel discouraged from contributing software. If it was made clear how easy most of the things you suggested actually are so that people did them as a matter of course, then the whole general standard of scientific software would increase.

The issue with a second round of peer review would be the time - where are we going to get that time from? At the same time, if people give and take at the same rate, it should result in better software and general benefits. It would also be something that you could put in a cover letter to help ease a paper through the journal.

(Related: I'd be interested to know what rejection rates actually are for software papers. I have my suspicions that they're quite low, just because by the time people getting around to doing them, the project has a far better defined scope than the "average" research project.)

@Gavin. Yes, aside from "abuses the software paradigm of language X" (which is very vague and thus a little difficult to evaluate), these all sound like terrific grounds for evaluating software. I see "novelty", "bugginess", "speed", and "documentation" in your list.
You make a good point about testing being especially useful for projects one is not planning to maintain oneself.

Examples are a simple practice, but for many people, even something as basic as a dynamic document isn't simple (how many packages have vignettes?). I think you, other ROpenSci folks, and a few other coders are far ahead of much of the field in terms of practices. This is quite useful (I tend you use you as guides: "We're moving away from svn -- should we go to git or mercurial? Ah, they've gone to git, let's use that. Julia sounds fast, should I start coding in that -- probably not, even they haven't started yet..."). However, if a year ago you were still learning the ins and outs of unit testing, it probably means that most people submitting software are not rejecting best practices, they just have no idea what they are.

This isn't to argue against high standards, and it's clear from your comments that you're not going to use your suggested standards as fixed "gatekeeping criteria". It's important to keep the overall field in sight, though. There are a lot of efforts to broaden the base of biologists who code. These neophytes are likely going to get some gruff but in the end helpful comments when they first try to upload to CRAN. If this is coupled by an outright rejection of a paper based on engineering concepts they've never heard of, they're going to think carefully before devoting time to writing software for the public in the future -- they might for later paper just append a text file in dryad. On the other hand, it doesn't help a field to have a lot of broken code around, especially if there are errors that quietly return inaccurate results, so code review is important. I just think these standards may be premature for where the field is now -- we need more education, first.

Thanks Brian.

I've recently switched from tacking ends on at the end as a chore to incorporating them more into the development cycle (sort of a Test-Driven-Development lite). Despite the usual criticisms (you don't know the output, hard for stochastic cases), I've found it a good match for how I was writing code anyway: write a piece, see if it works. The only difference now is that the "see if it works" part moves into a test suite.

The testthat package has definitely been key for this switch, with lots of different ways of running tests ranging from package-optimised to interactive-use-optimised.

I'm the editor of the Journal of Open Research Software, mentioned in Carl's post. We've been up and running for nearly a year and have been going through a number of iterations of our guidelines for reviewers (which I've posted as a reply below).

We've found it's a balance between the effort you place on the author and the reviewer.

At present, we believe it's appropriate to place additional effort on the author to make it easier to review, as long as any additional steps would also make it easier for a reader of the software paper to reuse the software. But still, it's not easy to be anything more than check that it runs. So we've focussed more on whether the software provides enough information so that the user understands whether it fits their needs. One issue we've had is trying to match reviewers to papers such that reviewers have an understanding of the general subject area. Another is matching reviewers who have access to the systems/hardware to run a piece of software.

Compared to Carl's review criteria, we ask for some and pass on others. Motivation, examples, license, development website, and support mechanisms are all examined closely. However in JORS, we are not considering things such as scalability/efficiency/robustness as major criteria in their own right (as opposed to what is necessary to enable reuse - for instance a certain level of robustness is required for reuse).

JORS Review Template

Decision: ACCEPT/ACCEPT AFTER MINOR REVISIONS/MAJOR REVISIONS REQUIRED/UNABLE TO REVIEW

Summary of Reviewers recommended revisions:
- please provide a list of your recommendations, indicating which are compulsory for acceptance and which are optional but would improve the quality of the paper or the reusability of the software.

The paper
a. Is the title of the paper descriptive and objective?
b. Does the Abstract give an indication of the software's functionality, and where it would be used?
c. Do the keywords enable a reader to search for the software?
d. Does the Introduction give enough background information to understand the context of the software's development and use?
e. Does the Implementation and Architecture section give enough information to get an idea of how the software is designed, and any constraints that may be placed on its use?
f. Does the Quality Control section adequately explain how the software results can be trusted?
g. Does the Reuse section provide concrete and useful suggestions for reuse of the software, for instance: other potential applications, ways of extending or modifying the software, integration with other software?
h. Are figures and diagrams used to enhance the description? Are they clear and meaningful?
i. Do you believe that another researcher could take the software and use it, or take the software and build on it?

The software
a. Is the software in a suitable repository? (see http://openresearchsoftware.me... for more information)
b. Does the software have a suitable open licence? (see http://openresearchsoftware.me... for more information)
c. If the Archive section is filled out, is the link in the form of a persistent identifier, e.g. a DOI? Can you download the software from this link?
d. If the Code repository section is filled out, does the identifier link to the appropriate place to download the source code? Can you download the source code from this link?
e. Is the software license included in the software in the repository? Is it included in the source code?
f. Is sample input and output data provided with the software?
g. Is the code adequately documented? Can a reader understand how to build/deploy/install/run the software, and identify whether the software is operating as expected?
h. Does the software run on the systems specified? (if you do not have access to a system with the prerequisite requirements, let us know)
i. Is it obvious what the support mechanisms for the software are?
