Thanks for the advice! I'm building a Jekyll site and it's good to see such an explicit walk-through of the decisions one would make in building one. Similarly, I'm glad you have such thorough notes in your GitHub Issues for the source. That will save me a lot of research time in my projects, for sure.

Maybe you've written about this previously, but do you have any concerns about the future-friendliness of Jekyll as a platform (particularly Liquid syntax mixed in with HTML/Markdown and the portability of configuration to other platforms) or is this just about as good as it gets? Having used Wordpress plenty and already preferring Markdown, I don't need to be sold on Jekyll, but will we feel the same way about Jekyll and its attendant technologies in 5 years as we do now, or doesn't it matter?

Great question; I share your sentiments I think. I try to avoid liquid code in my posts -- they are pure markdown (well, pandoc flavored markdown) with yaml headers, so should be somewhat independent of the Jekyll/Liquid platform, which mostly provides bells and whistles (aesthetic layout, sha hashes, twitter feeds, etc., the kind of content which is most likely to change in the future anyway). Hence the liquid code could be easily replaced while the modular nature of the html, markdown, and yaml, etc, (even the ruby plugins if desired) could be migrated.

Long term, I suspect UTF8 plain-text and HTML will be among the most durable formats. Having the content in clean, semantic html, and in plain-text (markdown) means it should be relatively easy to move content around to different platforms. Having migrated both a mediawiki site and a wordpress site into this Jekyll notebook without too much trouble, ( e.g. http://carlboettiger.info/2012... and http://carlboettiger.info/2012... ) I'm both cognizant that platforms are not forever but that intelligent formats preserve content reliably.

For the moment, I feel Jekyll is the best thing out there, at least as much because it is easy to extend then for what it already provides. This means it is easier to incorporate new technologies into Jekyll as we go along, but also to move to an entirely different platform if need be.

I'm a huge fan of reproducible research and automation and all that, but I think Markdown is more of a problem than a solution. First of all, we who work heavily in R / RStudio and on Github have *two* variants of Markdown to deal with - RStudio/knitr Markdown and Github-flavorer Markdown. I suppose if Yihui Xie and Hadley push hard enough on Tom Preston-Werner and Jekyll, some sort of merged Markdown *standard* could be fashioned that would meet our needs.

But the wider issue is that the *standards* are XHTML / EPUB 2 and HTML5 / EPUB3. The tools we use should make it easy for us to build accessible, *responsive* or even "mobile first" websites and ebooks that adhere to these standards. Markdown makes it easy for a *coder* to produce a literate program; the rest of the job isn't getting done. There's a huge difference between a one-pager on Rpubs and a publication I can ask someone to pay for with a straight face.

I've looked at some of the tools O'Reilly has for authoring/editing/publishing and I think they are an order of magnitude better than anything I've seen from the hacker community. Maybe "Github publishing" will get there some day, but I don't think we should have to wait.

Thanks for your perspective on it. I feel exactly the same way about platform-agnostic and semantic HTML (as well as plain-text/markdown), which is a large part of why I'm going to spend a lot of time getting into Jekyll. I'll have to balance out how much I rely on plugins and Liquid, but starting basic seems like the best strategy.

Given my currently rudimentary programming skills, I'm glad I'm not migrating from an existing platform, but it's good to know that it can be done.

I agree with you 100%, (X)HTML / HTML5 is the real standard and the goal here; which is what my whole post is about -- my pull request generates semantically, mobile ready rich HTML5 pages for the journal, and it says nothing about markdown after all. This is the "rest of the job" -- generating useful, rich, mobile-ready HTML5 from whatever tools the authors use (while also providing authors with easy tools for them to worry about content and not this stuff -- which is the part that is 'getting done' by markdown, and other tools).

In the end, Markdown is just a tool for authors; and authors will always have a variety of tools. Because we can fork the R journal, we can go ahead and make it more responsive, mobile-ready, provide tools to generate epub from XHTML/HTML5, etc, building pipelines to extract content from markdown, tex, Rnw, etc. What do you think?

That would be fantastic. Glad Hadley jumped at the suggestion of journals creating organizational accounts on GitHub and forking submissions. All the relevant metadata (author affiliations, submission type, etc can be in YML headers). Edward, while I agree that the standards are HTML and epub (I would exclude XHTML, as I don't see a future path for it), these are not necessarily the best authoring formats, and most of us who don't use an online editor will continue to write our content in other formats first. For me markdown is an alternative to LaTeX and Microsoft Word, not to HTML.

Unfortunately there are more than two markdown flavors, and this is a huge problem. I personally favor Pandoc as markdown processor, as it allows for some of the advanced features like citations to scholarly articles.

I think these are all excellent guidelines. I think our disagreement, as it were, was mainly due to a difference in the meaning of different degrees of reviewer recommendations (perhaps a cultural difference? I am a paleo person, after all). These guidelines, particularly the software guidelines, hit on what I agree with you should be required aspects: repository, license, etc. (I wonder what counts as sample input-output data? I didn't have 'real' example data in paleotree until a github commit I made just today; all the examples used simulation examples with a set random.seed.) I do think the extensibility recommendations you made were very good recommendations, but I think a strength of the above is the structure. By phrasing everything as questions, similar to the recent redesign of the PLOS reviewing system, I think it provides a valuable framework in which a reviewer can evaluate how well a paper meets the guidelines represented by each question. An author could also easily look at those questions before submission and know what the expectations were.

(All that aside, I'm still worried what it means for the review process in general if two people can interpret the typical reviewer recommendations so differently. Oh well.)

FYI, I notice that Dustin Mitchell has commented on G+ that a bug tracker (like in git) should be an important component.

It's a subtle point, but one important thing about this list is that it's questions for reviewers, not requirements for acceptance (or fixed standards for major revision, minor revision, etc.). Reviewers are asked to check these things (so as not to overlook them), not necessarily require them -- there's nothing here that mandates acceptance for open source software only, just ensures that the reviewer records whether it's open source or not [though as a reviewer, I'd almost always require openness]. It's also far less stringent than your tests: "identify whether the software is operating as expected" could be the automatic unit tests you'd require, but it could be manual: does the single input file generate the output file. For some software, such as something that's a GUI, automated tests of much of the main functionality might be practically impossible (though components inside could be subject to unit tests).

The last point is interesting: "Is it obvious what the support mechanisms for the software are?" As written, a possible response is, "Yes, it's obvious the authors are not planning to support this in the future" or "Yes, via a paid help subscription" [as happens with some open source projects]. However, given that the question is there, reviewers will tend to require some support set up, presumably free. It might be good to get into a discussion at some point of what support we should require for scientific software, in contrast to other scientific research output [do we require someone posting a table of data to deal with user requests to reformat it (csv to a particular xml spec, for example?]. And what about people planning to, say, retire in two years: should their software not be published unless someone else is signed up to take over? Presumably, well documented software with unit testing would allow someone else to support it later, if she/he so chose. But maybe hold off until after NSF deadlines for this discussion....

David, thanks for the reply, and nice to hear we are on the same page. Yes, I think these were the kinds of things I meant to say, but had phrased in terms of developer jargon that made them more onerous.

I don't interpret that input-output data has to be "real", simulated data should be fine (and preferable in some instances, since the generating process is known).

Yup, I agree that these guidelines are much better worded than mine (which sound more stringent than they are -- note I didn't require 'unit tests', etc). There's also stuff in here I didn't address.

Regarding what reviewers "require", I guess we have a difference of expectation in how the review system works though. I believe that reviewers make *recommendations* and editors make *decisions*. To me it is somewhat semantic whether I write "major revisions: I'd really like to see expected input and output I can run by copy and paste to verify if the software is working" or: "major revisions: software does not contain expected input/output". Regardless of the wording it is up to the editor to decide whether or not this change is "required" in my opinion.

Good comments about possible answers. I think you are spot on -- this is similar in my mind to NSF's "data management plan" approach. You can write: "this work does not have/need a plan to manage data" (or write this: http://ivory.idyll.org/blog/da... ), and it is up to the panel and ultimately the program officers making the decision to decide if that is acceptable. The point is simply to make these things explicit.

Thanks, Carl. I would think "Reject and resubmit" if there are no automatic tests constitutes requiring unit tests, but I might be missing something. You're right, though, that it's up to the editors for decisions (and as a reviewer I am sometimes overruled -- I think I tend to be too harsh).

And I love the link to the sample plan. Hmm, I'm working on a grant now....
I agree: having guidelines like the above would make intent clearer for reviewers (and for authors, too).

To be R-specific: I've never required someone use one of the unit test suites (testthat, or the more rigorous Runit, svUnit, etc), but I have asked for copy-paste code in the documentation examples. The trouble with just adding RDF is that a generic tool would not know what it was. While with RDFa (a for "annotate", right?) we annotate the document with semantics that can be extracted by a generic tool.

A few comments - and I know I'm coming quite late to the party! First, as reviewers I think using an explicit list of criteria is a fantastic idea. The discussion in this thread about "major revisions: do this" are really things that are in the hands of the Associate Editor. That is, as AE, I have some control over what is required, what is suggested, and what can be ignored from the reviews. This also means that if explicit criteria were applied at the journal level rather than just used by single reviewers, they would have more teeth.

Second, in my experience, the "bar" for software papers is steadily rising (this probably applies more generally to new comparative methods papers). What was acceptable even two or three years ago - maybe just a brief description of the package and a couple figures - might not be "good enough" to satisfy reviewers today. So the conversations happening on this blog are timely and important.

One reason why I've not commented on either of these threads so far is what feels like a contradiction in my thinking: (1) I think explicit criteria at the journal level would be much better than the current system, but (2) I'm not really sure what these criteria should be.

Finally, I think there is an additional piece to this puzzle: citations. Many of the things Carl mentions make a better paper, and might not be "required" by journals. But I am 100% sure that these things - especially re: sustainability - turn out to be excellent predictors of citation rates for the software. Even the citations themselves will be different. "Another cool method also exists (Weasel et al. 2008)." versus "We used Weasel et al. (2008) to do amazing things" - which is a huge difference for us as programmers, I think! And when we are on hiring committees, we can very easily see how often your papers are getting cited.

Now have a working solution using dual classes and assigning values as attributes rather than slots. Plenty to figure out still. See https://github.com/ropensci/re...

Carl, check out the `comment()` function as it allows things like adding units to variables in a data frame. Otherwise, I would consider a list containing a data frame as one component, then write methods for the various methods you need (`[.foo`, `[[.foo`, `[<-.foo`, `[[<-.foo` etc), or add a class to the data frame (`class(bar) <- c("foo", class(bar)`) and then put the things you want to store on to the data frame as attributes on the object. The latter allows you to leverage all the existing methods as R will cascade down the classes when doing method dispatch. However, some functions/methods may well loose the attributes so the former approach may be better or a hybrid, where you write specific methods for class `foo` only for those operations where you want the attributes preserved.

Also, I think the S4 business is just due to base R having S4 methods for data frames so they can work with S4 OOP as well as S3. Data frames are certainly S3 and it will probably be easier to think of them as such and work with them that way too.

Gavin, thanks much, this is pretty helpful stuff. `comment` looks promising but inadequate for my real objective here, which is attach the standard metadata that EML (the ecological metadata language) expects to have for a table (data.frame): see http://knb.ecoinformatics.org/... `comment` only permits character strings and clearly I need a bit more structure.

I see your point about thinking about `data.frame` as S3 that just happens to have S4 methods; it explains some of the oddities I observed above. Nevertheless, I've found it more useful to define my extension as an S4 class that mimics a `data.frame`, and then declared it as an extension of the S3 class: c("data.set", "data.frame"). I could write my `data.set` definition and methods in S3, but it seems to work just as well to write them in S4, giving me slightly more explicit method definitions. It would be invaluable to get your feedback on this as you may see things I missed. See my definitions here: https://github.com/ropensci/re...

My current approach allows me to define data.frames that inherit all the methods of data.frames while also having slots for the EML attribute metadata, eg: https://github.com/ropensci/re...

There are still several issues / open questions with this approach, see https://github.com/ropensci/re...

Got ya. I'd just be careful mixing S4 incantations and the use of the class(). My understanding is that that is for S3 classes. If you go the S4 route things are more involved in creating classes and you don't indicate inheritance this way. I may be out of touch though as I have barely dabbled with S4.

I am a bit confused. How can code review not be a good thing that every developer should be thankful for? Getiing code out there and ideally as open source is nice, but code quality is as important. Martin, thanks for your comments that cut to the heart of the issue, as always.

Re code review discouraging sharing, I think the concern is the majority of researchers who do not think of themselves as software developers yet nevertheless run some statistics in R or make some plots in Matlab. Almost no paper reporting a p value or a measure of statistical fit does so without code; almost none of them include that code, and I'd bet almost none of them would want to -- the best outcome would be neutral, the worst would be embarrassment. See Roger's version: http://simplystatistics.org/20...

Re Scientist vs software engineer; I think this proceedings piece by Neil Chue Hong and others nails it: http://dirkgorissen.com/2012/0... Briefly, scientists and software engineers do have different training and are measured / incentivised on different axes. In future we need folks along the entire spectrum they outline, but particularly the researcher software engineer that has the statistical and discipline-specific knowledge an industry software engineer lacks, but seek to measured on their software alone (though I place myself rather at the other end of that spectrum).

I really liked this post, and agree that publishing your hashes is a good thing. However, without third party verification, what is to stop you from doing git rebase, changing your data, and then publishing a new hash? Probably nobody would notice. Do you know of a way to verify the integrity of the data at a particular point in time without a third party (or is there a good third party out there that you don't need to pay for)?

Good question. The point here is only that the change would be detectable because the hash would have changed. Of course this can be done more directly by hashing just the page content, following Tobias's approach.

To have a verifiable copy, it would be necessary to cite the hash when citing the article; most simply by appending it to the URL. For example, the current version of this page is: http://carlboettiger.info/2013... If the hash on the page doesn't match the hash in that URL, then the page has changed since I made that link.

To verify that the hash displayed on the page truly matches the page content requires cloning the whole git repository. Tobias's approach is much more practical: just compute the hash of the page content and see if it matches the hash in the identifier (URL).

hehe, I'm not always careful with my choice of language on my blog. I'm sure I do lots of things that are not best practice as well; and we can collectively blame R for making it easy to do things wrong. Because an object can have multiple classes, it makes sense to me that one would not want to check the class with a direct comparison of strings, `class(obj) == "phylo"`, since that would fail of class was c("myclass", "phylo"). However, I think it is less obvious that not all the classes an object has are returned by `class`, e.g. you might think `!is.na(match("phylo", class(obj)))` sufficient work-around for multiple classes, but it isn't. For the example in this post, `class(b)` above returns only `nexmlTree`. However, note that the related function `inhertits(b, "phylo")` returns true, as well as `is(b, "phylo")`. Inheritance is more subtle. I don't know of a simply way to get a list of all classes an object inherits, so boo R.

Not sure if that explanation helps at all. As much as I go on about raising the bar for scientific software, I think some issues we hit must be laid at the feet of the languages themselves. I am a Scientist and I write lots of code. Code that is throw-away code. I name my variables "stuff" and "crap" because my only goal is to write the code in a quick manner for a very very specific task. Will someone find that code useful someday? Maybe. The real question is how will someone even find a piece of code so highly specific? Where does one search? What search terms does one use?

If someone is a competent programmer they would rather spend the 30 minutes to 1 hour writing their own code then trying to find and use someone else's code.
There is no standard for input files. I enjoy ":" separating my data other people use spaces or multiple spaces or commas, &c. This reduces code re-usability even when looking at the same or similar data. Again, being able to reuse code is really only useful for massive software projects and then I don't even care what the code looks like because I just want to use it. If it runs I will use. If not I won't.

Do I test my code? Yes. Do I verify my code? Yes. Could I say that I have never written code that made an error? NO. Can anyone?
Either the goal is to find errors in people's code or it is not. And it seems like they are trying to pretend like the goal is NOT to find errors which seems unlikely. If they find an error will they just ignore it? This becomes scary then. Why should I submit my code to anything when a simple mistake could make my research all over the news a la Excel Spreadsheet. Scientists are under enough scrutiny and pressure already.

Instead what Mozilla should do is volunteer to write software solutions to common Scientific problems people come upon. This would decrease errors by people using standard and scrutinized code and wouldn't make anyone feel vulnerable.

@Josiah Thanks for your comments, I suspect your perspective is commonly held in our research community. I don't mean to critique your approach, but I think part of the reason this attitude is widespread is because there is little reward for doing otherwise.

Setting aside the much smaller amount of code researchers write as dedicated software explicitly for re-use of other scientists (as discussed in the Science article i cite above), where I suspect we can agree code review could play a clear role, I agree that discussion here is more about what to do, if anything, regarding the small bits of 'throw-away' code you and the rest of us regularly use.

The purpose of publishing this code in the first place is to document what was done -- a standard expectation of all scientific publishing. Yes, code is messy. So is the rest of scientific experimental methodology. The methods section does not ask you to publish your whole lab notebook; or describe how sample 3 was misplaced and controls 2-4 were left out of the fridge by accident. Instead, the expectation is to publish a clean and precise account of the steps necessary to repeat the work.

Do journals require methods sections just to find errors? Of course not. Certainly that is one important reasons why a methods section should be included, but obviously research builds on existing methods sections as well.

Why shouldn't code be held to a similar standard? Code makes it easier to understand what an author has done -- even pseudocode is rarely sufficient to precisely replicate results, as Ince et al argue in Nature piece I cite above. Yes, seeing code can help catch errors, but I disagree that that is the only objective. Code can be useful for communicating methods, and review can improve the effectiveness of that communication by improving the syntax, just as peer review does with the text and figures. And yes, I believe published code can very much be reused. I've frequently reused bits of published scripts that do the basic data cleaning and aggregation steps before applying a method I'm interested in, and likewise have fed other data into existing code to compare results. Yes, this would be easier with standard data structures, which is a good reason for code review that would end up saving all of us a lot of time.

Yes, this probably means rewriting messy code to be cleaner -- probably a more useful activity than the hours we spend checking the grammar and punctuation of our prose. As I have improved my own coding habits I've found that I'm the one who most benefits anyway, as I'm the one most likely to go back to the code. If reviewers wanted to offer further suggestions, I'm sure they would me more valuable to me than when they point out my misuse of the Oxford comma. Experimental labs almost always emphasize precise and pedantic practice in handling and labelling of materials -- why should computational work be so much more sloppy?

Thanks for this post Carl. I think this is pretty spot on. A few comments to add to this.

So first "phylogenetic signal" is in my view a pretty meaningless quantity anyway. Different values of lambda can come about by a bunch of processes (Revell et al. 2008 Sys Bio). It is difficult to conceive of a situation where different lambda values can tell you something meaningful about the ecology or evolution of a trait.

Second, if one wants to quantify how much information content the phylogeny contains regarding the trait value, a potentially useful thing to consider is the "phylogenetic half-life". This can be computed for any model and thought of "the amount of time it takes before half the information content in the phylogeny is eroded". I like your suggestion of using alpha from an OU model but to me a more intuitive way of thinking about this is to use alpha to calculate the half-life. For an OU model, this is simply ln(2)/alpha. Note that a phylogenetic half-life can also be computed for discrete characters. For a simple 2-state mk model where the instantaneous rate of transition from state 0 to 1 is q01 and the reverse is q10, the phylogenetic half-life is simply ln(2)/(q01+q10).

Third, a more complicated question is what lambda means when used in the context of phylogenetic regression (this was developed in Freckleton et al. 2002 Am Nat and has been frequently used and recommended; see Revell 2010 MEE). Hansen and Orzack (2005 Evolution) make the case that this is formally equivalent to "phylogenetic heritability" as estimated from a mixed effects model from Quantitative Genetics (see Lynch 1991 Evolution, Housworth et al. 2004 Am Nat, Hadfield and Nakagawa 2010 JEB). This is a rather nice result and worth looking at. However, if our question is whether trait Y is an adaptation to trait X, using Pagel's lambda or BM (such as in PICs or "standard" PGLS) may be inappropriate. There is an excellent discussion of this in the aforementioned Hansen and Orzack paper as well as in Hansen et al. 2008 Evolution and Hansen and Bartoszek 2012 Sys Bio. All are worth reading.

Matt, thanks for your thoughts and excellent references, in particular I hadn't seen the arguments of Hansen and Orzack before. I probably have to spend a bit more time with that (it would be nice if they wrote more than "it is straight forward to show..."). While their analogy between lambda and H^2 is interesting, I don't feel this offers me any reassurance that lambda is doing something biologically relevant and fear that the equivalence they point to is very superficial. heritability does not have a notion of 'branch length', being defined relative to a pedigree. I think it is bold to map the last observed speciation event (noting that we may be missing more recent nodes do to missing taxa or extinction, etc) to a pedigree. Without either the problems of branch lengths or missing taxa I discuss here, the analogous calculation in heritability does not share the pitfalls that bother me here.

I quite like your term "phylogenetic half-life"; indeed, that is much more to the point!
The term 'phylogenetic half-life' or sometimes 'phylogenetic half-time' dates to Hansen (1997; Evolution pp. 1348), I believe.

I must be missing something. Low values of alpha = strong phylogenetic signal, but low alpha values are associated with low power when I use PMC. How can you have strong phylogenetic signal and low power?

I'm also missing this: "The OU or BM model estimates made by researcher 1 will closely agree with with those of Researcher 1."

Hi Chris, thanks for asking. Recall that the frequentist concept of power must be defined in reference to some test -- if the alpha value is very small, we have a harder time distinguishing it from Brownian motion then if it has a much larger value -- e.g. we may lack the power to reject the null model. (Having low alpha by itself does not necessarily mean that the data has "low power", alpha is essentially the effect size. Power is a property of the data under a test, not a property of an estimated parameter.) So the two statements you make are really two ways of saying the same thing: small alpha values look more like Brownian motion than larger ones. Make sense?

Yes, clearly one of those should have been researcher "2". Thanks for catching that.

FYI:

1. Info-gap decision theory (IGDT) is fundamentally flawed in the manner in which it treats severe uncertainty. See http://info-gap.moshe-online.c...

2. Info-gap's robustness model is a reinvention of a maximin model that is known universally as Stability Radius (circa 1960).

(I remember reading this somewhere and it jiving with the massive variance in my alpha estimates that I was looking at at the time, so I accepted it without committing the source to memory... so maybe it's complete BS). Or am I missing something?

Hi Luke, Large alpha will be unstable in so much as one large alpha will look like another; recall all large alpha values are essentially the same thing: exp(- alpha t) when alpha is big is something pretty small, so not much phylogenetic signal. So this doesn't really bother me. If alpha is near zero (relative to the branch lengths in the tree), we can say we have a signal of phylogenetic inertia, and we can make that statement relative to the part of the tree in which we observe it.

As I've argued above, lambda's numerical stabilities are more troublesome, as is it's interpretation as a property of the "whole tree" which ends up being a rather arbitrary scale and sensitive to who you include in the tree and who you don't.
